title: this election is not all about brexit its also a choice between state control and freedom
story: The Conservatives pledge to take us out of the European Union, the Lib Dems vow to keep us in and Labour promise to prolong the agony for another year or three.Brexit is, of course, a central issue. But something even more important is at stake.Do we want to continue to live with the free-market economy that has given us wealth unimaginable a century ago  Or do we want to be sucked backwards into the failed socialist experiment that impoverished Eastern Europe in the second half of the th century and has laid waste to Venezuela Labour has yet to produce the radical manesto Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell promised yesterday but we already know there is going to be a hike in income tax for those earning over £, a year — and probably a swingeing wealth tax, given McDonnell’s past enthusiasm for the idea.McDonnell, too, has said he would expropriate ten per cent of the shares of every British company and put them in a fund supposedly for the benefit of the workers — although when you read the small print, workers would receive a maximum of £ in idends per year, with the rest going straight into the Government’s coffers.That measly £ would do little to compensate for the collapse in value of pension funds as Labour nationalised water and electricity companies at below the market value of their shares.Many of those shares are owned by funds on which you and I rely for our retirement.The Shadow Chancellor promises that under Labour, we will only have to work a four-day, -hour week, apparently with no cut in pay. We might as well put Alice In Wonderland in charge of the economy. His sums simply don’t add up.McDonnell says he will increase the National Living Wage to £ an hour. Butlow-paid workers were stopped from working  hours a week rather than the current average of , it would mean a substantial cut in pay for millions of people.That Theresa May was unable to win an outright majority against Jeremy Corbyn and his extreme economic policies in  is as astonishing in retrospect as it was at the time. What was meant to be a coronation nearly turned into a wake. Many Conservatives fear the polls could turn sharply again.But there is scant sign Boris Johnson will repeat Mrs May’s abysmal campaign. His three months in office have brought a change in the weather. We have a Prime Minister who exudes optimism rather than a sense of defeat.While May seemed almost embarrassed to be a Conservative and tried to out-do Labour for proposing the most unappealing tax rise — the “dementia tax” — Johnson has made the case for capitalism and conservatism.The first of those, he rightly points out, pays for the public services we all value so much.He has promised to rebuild hospitals and reverse the cuts in police numbers that took place on Mrs May’s watch.He knows the way to improve the lot of people on low incomes is not to boost benefits but to increase earnings through a higher ­National Living Wage.But he also recognises middle-income groups have suffered disproportionately from the tax system in recent years and has proposed raising the threshold for the  per cent tax rate.While Corbyn and McDonnell would undermine livelihoods by cutting working hours, Johnson’s Tories will encourage us to work and to invest — in our homes, in pensions and savings. Rather than threaten businesses with confiscating shares, he promises better infrastructure, especially broadband.Boris doesn’t just want to get Brexit done, as Remainer Mrs May did.He wants to turn it to Britain’s advantage, opening our economy to the world beyond the EU, with new trade deals to bring in investment.While Mrs May created a hostile environment for migrants, Johnson has indicated a more welcoming attitude towards those who want to come to Britain to work.But more than that, it is a battle between enterprise and overbearing State control, between having the freedom to invest for your future and having your assets confiscated, between the opportunity to work and having your working hours laid down by the Government.It is a cliche to say we face the most important election in decades. But this time it really is true.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: corbyn zealots cant fit world in boxes
story: But this week, the world received a rare bit of sanity from a surprising source.Despite being something of a messianic figure among the “progressive” young, Barack Obama attacked the very culture they aspire to.In an interview for his Obama Foundation’s annual summit in Chicago on Tuesday, he laid into “wokeness” and young people who are obsessed with “purity”.Obama told his audience: “I get a sense among certain young people on social media that the way of making change is to be as judgemental as possible about other people.”Hear, bloody, hear.This was not the only important segment of his talk, which contained huge lessons for whippersnappers.He also said, “the world is messy, there are ambiguities” and, “people who do really good stuff have flaws”.Obama’s address could not have come at a more important time, particularly given the major culture wars that are being fought in the West.Something that is completely absent from our debates, and arguably driving new tensions, is the idea that le is “messy”, as Obama says, and requires compromise.Instead, we are seeing activists treat issues asthey can be put in neat little boxes — with a right and wrong answer.This is part of the reason why university campuses have become such toxic places.They are incubators for hysteria, where students act like religious zealots, banning celebrated academics such as Germaine Greer for not spouting their approved doctrines.Twitter, too, is being used to hound others for having “incorrect” views, with pile-ons and clips circulated of the “blasphemous”.Say something “wrong” and you are “cancelled”. No debate.This extremism is feeding into real-le events, including the campaign for next month’s General Election. Just look at the Labour Party and its leader Jeremy Corbyn.Despite presenting himself as a kind and compassionate old bean, Corbyn and most MPs in the current Labour Party thrive on presenting society as a fight between “good” and “evil”, the “few” and “many”, with people like bankers and Tories in the latter group.At every chance they demonise anyone who strays from the progressive orthodoxy.Labour’s shouty MP David Lammy even took this philosophy so far as to compare Jacob Rees-Mogg’s hard Brexit European Research Group to “Nazis” and “apartheid”.In reality, they are simply politicians who have dferent views to him.But such extreme rhetoric has become normalised among Labour. You are either on their side of the argument, or you are a fascist.Labour’s polarised world view is encapsulated in its utterly bonkers set of policies.Any sensible government knows that economic reform takes time, and is often about compromise and improving existing structures.But Labour wants to tear everything down and start again, with private schools being top of the list — no doubt because MPs have a vendetta against Etonians.Corbyn also wants to abolish Universal Credit, despite having no tangible plan for its replacement.Universal Credit is the perfect example of where Labour goes wrong. The system has had teething issues but the answer is not to burn it down, it is to make slow improvements.There are other huge, sweeping pledges the party has made, such as nationalising the railways, water, energy and mail, seizing a ten per cent stake in every private company with more than  staff and having a target of net zero for carbon emissions by .Experts have suggested this could lead to meat being rationed, cars confiscated and the wholesale closure of industries .Who cares, though,it gets Labour in charge!Much of the reason Labour has set upon these radical policies is because shaking up the system is always incredibly exciting for the young, particularlyit looks like it might bring about a few freebies.And let’s face it, it is no surprise that millennials and their younger counterparts can be enticed.They have had a rough ride since the  financial crisis, absorbing the shock of the recession and being decades away from home ownership.It is no wonder they think socialism is the answer, especially as it plays into the woke mindset of there being simple, binary solutions to everything.This is why it is so important that young people actually take on what Obama was saying about the world.The Government has to make large numbers of deeply complex decisions, where there cannot always be winners.Almost always someone will lose out in the intricate interplay that is political decision-making.There needs to be more acceptance of a Margaret Thatcher-style realism: That le is not fair.That is something youngsters do not seem to grasp these days, believing equalities can be remedied with the magic wand of socialism.Strong, long-lasting policies do not make sexy soundbites like “For the many”, nor can they be advertised in protests outside Parliament Square. Like Obama said, the world is messy.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bacon shortage african swine fever spreading
story: The speed at which the deadly animal virus has been spreading across Asia has taken policy makers by surprise. Globally, it has been found in  countries, including Poland, Russia, South Korea and the Philippines, killing hundreds of million pigs, while reshaping global meat and feed markets.But Monique Eloit, who heads the World Organisation for Animal Health , said: The risk exists for ALL countries, whether they are geographically close or geographically distant because there is a multitude of potential sources of contamination.We are really facing a threat that is global. While African swine fever is not harmful to humans, it can be transmitted by a tourist bringing back a ham or sausage sandwich from a contaminated country.Should infected pork, for example, but thrown in the bin it could be reused by farmers to feed their pigs who will almost certainly diethey contract it.  China, the world’s largest producer of pork, has seen a  per cent reduction in its hog population due to swine fever. And it is feared should the disease turn into a pandemic a similar reduction would be reflected globally.  The disease has spread rapidly to several countries in Southeast Asia including Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos, Korea and the Philippines and more countries are likely to be hit in the coming months.This outbreak of the virus is believed to have originated from Africa and then spread to Georgia through the transportation of pig products.The spread was believed to have been worsened by wild boars. Insects including ticks may also be responsible.The virus can survive after the animal has died, it can live on in processed meat for up to a few months and in frozen meat for up several years.Currently the disease cannot be passed onto humans, although there are concerns about future mutations potentially affecting mankind.US pork sales to bacon blighted China have doubled, while European pork prices have reached a six-year high.OIE Vice-president Dr Mark Schipp said the swine fever was the biggest threat to any commercial livestock of our generation.But take a look at what this virus is doing around the globe today. And then look at the way goods and people travel.This would have a devastating effect on our industry. It’s the nastiest disease we have on the planet.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: entitled buffon chippy ex student no10
story: Surely we deserve better than a bumptious, entitled ­buffoon and a chippy ex- student inhabiting No . Are these two really the brightest and the best  Obviously not. But with politics becoming ever more isive and toxic, they are all we have left.Let’s be honest. What normal human being would want to be part of such a cesspit  As we are all well aware, the past three years have seen a constipated parliament unable, or unwilling, to sort out Brexit, forcing us all into a nightmarish version of Groundhog Day.I believe the idea of a European referendum was the height of stupidity by a spooked David Cameron who wanted to neuter Nigel Farage. When the nation voted Leave, Cameron was the first to abandon ship.Never mind “women and children first”. He was rowing away from a Titanic mess in a leboat stuffed with like-minded, snivelling clowns, leaving poor Theresa May behind playing an out-of-tune piano with the rest of the ship’s doomed orchestra. Mrs May foolishly called an election that was a personal disaster, then was worn down until she had to step aside.Boris Johnson thought he could bluster and blag his way to a solution and promised we would exit the EU a couple of days ago, on Halloween. For all his blather about “dying in a ditch”, he couldn’t deliver.So here we are, facing a pre-Christmas election at a time when distrust of politicians has never been higher and our expectations have been never lower. It is easy to dismiss the whole bloody lot of them as a waste of time.But there ARE some decent MPs who want to make a dference. Sadly, some are unwilling to put up with the scrutiny and vilication the job now entails and many are heading out the door.Female MPs, in particular, have been subjected to online abuse that chills the blood. As well as death threats, they have had to deal with vile monsters threatening rape and other violent attacks. It’s horric to have to cope with such hideous abuse on a daily basis. I can’t blame them for quitting in despair.Their fears are real. We saw that with the tragic murder of MP Jo Cox in . She was a we and mother who wanted to make the world a better place and do the best possible job for her constituents. It’s a real pity the MPs now calling it a day are mainly moderates who were calm ­voices of reason amid all the shrieking and howling from extremists on both sides of the political ide.Heidi Allen, a Tory who joined the Lib Dems, can no longer cope with the “nastiness and intimidation” which has become the norm in Parliament. Culture Secretary Nicky Morgan is leaving because the abuse towards her has had a “clear impact” on her ­family.The Tory and the Labour leaderships should hang their heads in shame at allowing such an appalling situation to develop. They should have called off their attack dogs and clamped down on cowardly online trolls.There have always been robust arguments and passionate debates in politics — but nothing like the sheer hatred and aggression Brexit has unleashed. MPs were used to attacks from opposing parties. But now some of the worst abuse comes from inside.Left-wing extremists threaten deselection for Labour MPs who even whisper about their discontent with Corbyn. Tories find themselves booted out for failing to toe the line. Sadly, the next six weeks will see even more of this aggression as we have to listen to hate-filled rants and ­ludicrous, undeliverable ­promises to secure our votes.It is strange to think that Westminster was respected and admired not so very long ago. I honestly don’t think those days will ever . We deserve so much better.SOME welcome good news comes in the form of Richard and Judy, who will pop back on to our TV screens to front the show they helped make such a huge success.It was meant to be a one-off when they presented This Morning a couple of weeks ago. But viewers were so excited, “R and J” have an open invitation to .The stumbling block has always been because Judy was reluctant toto live national TV. But Richard told me this week she really enjoyed herself and loved reconnecting with This Morning’s loyal audience.Richard was quick to stress that they are not after anyone’s jobs or in the market for a permanent– but it would be lovely to pop in now and again. I’m delighted. They are both total pros who make it all look delightfully easy and relaxed.They also have the sort of public affection only enjoyed by the Queen and Dame Judi Dench.IT is heartbreaking to think Ben Needham would have turned  this week. He has been for ever frozen in time as that little blond toddler playing in the Greek sunshine before going missing on Kos back in .Brave mum Kerry has never once stopped fighting to discover the truth. Three years ago, British police finally conducted a thorough investigation.They believe Ben was killed in an accident involving a digger on a building site on the island, where his grandad worked and close to where the family lived at the time. Despite handing over their evidence to authorities on the island, there have been no further attempts to find Ben’s body.Poor Kerry should have been celebrating her grown-up son’s milestone birthday, perhaps with her daughter-in-law and grandchildren. Instead, her agony ­continues.She has no closure, no grave to visit and is no nearer to finding out exactly what happened to her son almost three decades ago.I CAN’T wait to see what Michelle Visage and Giovanni Pernice have in store for us on Strictly Come Dancing. Last week their Halloween routine was perfection and Michelle foxtrotted around the floor like a gothic goddess.She was my tip to make the final even before the first steps were taken in this year’s competition. I knew Michelle had the sass, talent and work ethic to go all the way. I love that she’s flying the flag for the over-s while exuding buckets of sex appeal.Don’t forget that for years Michelle suffered with a serious autoimmune disease she believes was caused by her breast implants. She has only just recovered from surgery to have them removed.Michelle is a steel magnolia and the best is yet to come. So make sure you give her and Giovanni your vote.A HUGE thank you to everyone who has been so positive about Shine, my book out this week.With my th birthday coming up at the end of this month, it felt like a good time to reflect and take stock. I also wanted to share all of the knowledge and advice I’ve acquired from so many of the guests and experts I’ve met over the  years I’ve been on TV.So I decided to put it all into a book that will hopefully give useful tips and information to make your le better. I want it to be a book you can have by your bedside, to dip into when you need a bit of a confidence boost or advice on looking good and feeling great.I’m doing some signings on Saturday, so do pop in and say hello at WH Smith in Glasgow’s St Enoch Centre at noon and at Waterstones on Princes Street in Edinburgh at pm.I WAS in the US last week, going through astronaut training at Nasa. I will tell you about that very soon. But I also managed a couple of days to recover in Florida’s Key West. My husband and I had no idea that at this time of year there is a little event called Fantasy Fest. Well. What an eye-opener that was.Some brave souls were out and about in nothing more than expertly applied body paint. I was a bit bemused at first and obviously I refrained from joining in.But it is amazing how quickly you get used to someone wearing nothing but a leather posing pouch standing at the bar talking to you about the latest Trump baloney.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: greta thunberg kids terrified
story: Scientists have discovered that around , years ago, a new sort of animal started wandering around in a bit of Africa we now call Botswana. It was called “man”.He was hemmed in on all sides by giant deserts he couldn’t cross because, at this point, God had not invented the Land Rover. But it didn’t matter back then because this part of the world was full of all the food and water the mans and womans would ever need.It was lush, green and beautul. Everyone was very happy. Now, imaginethey’d known the planet was about to wobble on its axis, which would cause us to start on an all-new orbit around the sun.Imagine the panic. Imagine how many Greta Thunbergs would have rampaged about the place, blaming their elders for the mess and the certain death that faced them all. All the usual routes to the ­watering holes and fruit trees would have been blocked by ­activists in weird costumes saying a whole new way of le had to be adopted to stave off disaster.Everyone would have been told to go vegan and stop wearing shoes made from leather. But they didn’t know the Earth was about to wobble. They just woke up one morning to find the climate had changed.It was warmer and wetter. In fact, there was so much rain, the deserts surrounding them came to le. This meant they could explore strange new worlds and boldly go where no one had gone before.They moved to Europe and Asia. They spread out across the seas and soon, they came up with ­literature and agriculture and architecture and medicine. They became civilised and happy and healthy. And then they started going on holidays and drinking beer and laughing on the way home from the pub with their friends and a delicious kebab.And then they got next-day delivery on anything they wanted and a new smartphone every year and Instagram. One day, a tall man with a motoring show on the television was even able to drive a Lancia right across the salt pans where it all began. And all of that was possible thanks to a big, juicy lump of global warming.That’s the thing about climate change. We keep being told the next sht will be a disaster for mankind. But who knows  You might wake up one morning to find your garden full of unicorns and mermaids and big chests full of jewels and money.LOTS of people are wondering why Jeremy Corbyn took so long to agree to an election. But the answer is simple.Corbyn knew the longer he could stall Brexit, the more damage would be done to the one thing he hates more than everything : Britain. He’s always sided with anyone who wants to do us harm. The IRA. Hamas. Russia. You name it.He wants everyone in those camps in Calais to come here because he knows it will destabilise our way of le. In fact, every one of his policies is designed specically to ruin the country.Because that’s what the bitter and twisted weasel wants. Mind you, the Shadow Chancellor is even worse.Which isn’t strictly trueyou’ve got a one-off Ferrari  Speciale MM. APPARENTLY Daniel Craig was fed up with saying: “The name’s Bond. James Bond.” Well, I’m sorry, my precious, but you’re not getting any sympathy here. If you’ve worked in a poultry farm for  years, you can say you’re fed up with chickens.Andyou’ve worked on the railways all your adult le, you can say you are looking forward to a retirement without trains. But you, Mr Craig, only said that line FIVE times. Which is hardly taxing, is it No matter. There’s talk about who will replace him in the role. And because Bond is so woke and #MeToo these days, we cannot rule out the possibility that the role will be given to Diane Abbott or Janet Street-Porter.Some of me hopes he really does die in the new movie, as has been rumoured. Buthe doesn’t, might I suggest the part is given to a chap called Geoffrey Moore, top I met him at a party once and was impressed by his louche, charming style, his clever eyebrow work and his bright orange skin that even David Dickinson would call “over the top”.I’m not sure he can act. But that doesn’t matter because neither could his father Roger . . . and he was the best Bond of them all.BAD news. It seems the plug has been pulled on the hotly anticipated prequel to Game Of Thrones.They had a stellar cast including the brilliant Naomi Watts. And it was being written by Jane Goldman, the brains behind Kick-Ass and Kingsman. And her husband Jonathan Ross.HBO, though, has obviously decided the end result won’t work, which begs a question: How can they know I’ve worked in television for  years butsomeone came to me and said: “We have a show featuring an old lady baking cakes” I’d have put their ideas in a big bag of rubbish, along with that hare-brained scheme to stage a prime-time dancing competition.GATWICK airport is set to roll out a new system to cut boarding times and reduce delays.Sounds clever, yes. But it means you won’t be able to board with your family.And it does nothing to address the main problem: People who board with fridge freezers they’ve bought in duty free and which won’t fit in the overhead lockers.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: labour house prices rocketing green gadgets
story: Labour is today unveiling plans to force all new homes to meet tough rules to make them zero carbon.The party said this “demanding new requirement” would probably mean all new homes are fitted with triple glazing, insulation and solar .And they may not be fitted out with gas boilers as standard – used by many homes for central heating.The party said their plan to make all new homes zero-carbon within three years could save families £ a year in energy bills.Corbyn said: “Homes should be safe and warm for families and not damage the environment for future generations.“But our housing currently contributes a massive  per cent of the UK’s greenhouse gas emissions.“We will tackle the housing and climate crises at the same time by building warm and energy efficient homes.But the free-market think-tank the Institute of Economic Affairs IEA blasted the move.They warned it will push up property prices, discourage developers from building more homes, and kick people off the housing ladder.IEA head of political economy Dr Kristian Niemietz stormed: “What the UK housing market needs right now is less red tape, not more.“The UK already has some of the highest housing costs in the developed world.“Creating new rules that would push up the price of homes, without doing anything simultaneously to tackle sky-high house prices, will result in making it even harder for people to get onto the housing ladder.“If Labour, or any party for that matter, wants to address housing, they need to reform the flaws in our planning system, release more greenbelt land and reduce tax distortions such as Stamp Duty.”Housing Secretary Robert Jenrick blasted Labour’s plans.He said: “As usual, Labour is setting unrealistic targets that would slow down housebuilding and put up house title: brexit party votes corbyn no10
story: Nigel Farage will not be Prime Minister. Nor is he remotely likely to hold the balance of power.There is no longer a route to the No Deal Brexit he wants. Nor any prospect of Boris Johnson caving to his demands for a pact, destroying the Tories’ unity. And it is patently untrue to say Boris’s deal is not Brexit. The Tory ERG simply wouldn’t back itso.It will end our membership, payments and free movement and extract us from the customs union and single market, with no “backstop” keeping us half-in. We would trade freely as an independent nation. And Boris alone can get us out. The sole alternative as PM is Corbyn, and he will keep us in the EU for ever.In a few constituencies Farage’s party could hurt Labour more than the Tories. Overall it is FAR more likely to prevent Boris winning the majority which is vital to delivering Brexit and without which it is lost. That is why Farage’s ultimatum to the PM delighted Labour.Two by-elections — in Peterborough and Brecon, both of which the Tories should have won — were gted to Labour and the Lib Dems by Brexit Party votes. On December , those could put Corbyn in Downing Street in a Remain coalition.At which point Farage’s legacy won’t just be that his vanity wrecked his le’s work.That a party he founded with only one aim, a real Brexit, became the very instrument of the project’s destruction.He will be remembered as the right-wing maverick who handed anti-Semitic, anti-Western Marxists an unprecedented chance to plunder the world’s fth-largest economy. The Sun admires Farage.His pressure brought about the referendum AND a better deal. But he could now be the author of a double national catastrophe.He and his voters should think again.WE’VE heard it all now.Labour’s Tom ­Watson, of all people, insists broadcasters must combat the Tories’ “fake news”.That’s the same Tom Watson who destroyed lives spreading a paedophile’s lies.Whose party’s campaign centres on a blatant fiction about Boris “selling the NHS to Trump”.Whose leader lies endlessly about his terrorist sympathies and anti-Semitism — then sinisterly orders reporters: “Just report what we say.”These charlatans lecture journalists about the truth.But they themselves are strangers to it.Andthey took power, Press freedom would be a nostalgic memory.The Sun joins everyone rooting for Owen and England’s rugby heroes.Best of ruck, lads!Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris centre of attention may
story: “I feel confident, but then I felt confident in ,” one leading Cabinet Minister tells me.There is a Tory fear that ­history could repeat itself — that Jeremy Corbyn could surge again and an election designed to deliver a majority for Brexit could once more lead to a hung Parliament. But oddly,  is one of the things that mean the Tories might win that majority this time round. They are determined not to make the same mistakes again. As one senior party figure puts it: “We screwed it up once. We’re not going to do that again.”When Chancellor Sajid Javid spoke to Tory MPs on Wednesday night, he reassured them that “this campaign will not be like last time”. He described Theresa May’s  effort as “the most incompetent election campaign in modern times”.In , the Tories assumed that their chunky poll lead would easily translate into a big majority. There was a complacency and cockiness about their campaign. There was no ­rationale for why Mrs May was going back on her pledge not to have an election and a belief that the Tories could use that lead to win a mandate for almost anything.This time round, the Tories are being much more cautious. The groundwork has been laid for this campaign. Conservative Campaign HQ has been getting election-ready for months. The Tories have heavy-hitters ready to join their ­campaign team, including Paul Stephenson, one of the key ­figures from Vote Leave’s  victory. In , Mrs May took her own party machine by ­surprise with her decision to go to the country.In another dference with the ex-PM, Boris Johnson has a clear argument for why an ­election is needed — the only thing this Parliament is capable of on Brexit is delay. It is hard to see how anyone who wants Brexit and has seen what has happened since the  election could disagree with that.This Tory desire not to screw up will also lead to more ­discipline. This time, the ­manesto will be a cautious document, not an attempt to gain a mandate for a series of deeply unpopular reforms. The fact that everyone knows this election will be close helps the Tories too. There’ll be much more scrutiny of what a Corbyn premiership would mean than there was in .Cabinet Ministers believe that the prospect of a Labour SNP deal which would see Nicola Sturgeon’s Scottish Nationalists help Corbyn into Downing Street in exchange for another independence referendum is already cutting through, and particularly in Scotland, where the Tories are increasingly ­confident they can limit their losses to five seats or fewer.But perhaps the biggest dference from  is between Johnson and May. May had never done a ­national campaign before, she disliked big events and preferred going door to door. Boris, by contrast, is a showman who has already ­successfully fronted one nationwide effort, the  referendum. Boris knows how to make himself the centre of attention in a way Mrs May never did.As one Cabinet minister puts it: “Boris is ­capable of stealing the oxygen from all the other candidates.”The most signicant threat to the Tories is pro-Remain tactical voting. The big question, frets one Cabinet minister, is whether Labour and the Lib Dems end up splitting the ­centre-left vote and letting the Tories win — as happened with Labour and the SDP in  — or whether there is anti-Tory voting that condemns scores of previously safe Tory MPs to defeat — as happened in .Butthe Tories avoid the pitfalls of , then even from a much less promising starting position they should be able to win a majority.THIS election will see the first ever head-to-head televised leaders’ debate between the two big parties. On November , Jeremy Corbyn and Boris Johnson will clash in primetime on ITV. Both Labour and the Tories think they will benefit from this one-on-one format.On the Labour side, they hope that it helps them unite the anti-Tory vote behind Corbyn. The Tories think the question of who you want to be Prime Minister – Johnson or Corbyn – favours them.During the  campaign, Theresa May lost her lead on this question. But right now, Boris Johnson has a -point advantage over Corbyn. If he can maintain anything like this margin, he’ll still be in No  come Christmas.Downing Street also thinks that making this election a forced choice between a Tory government and a Labour government works to their benefit. Polling for Conservative Campaign HQ shows that half of voters want the Tories in government in some way, compared to just over a quarter for Labour.They calculate that making the election a choice between Johnson and Corbyn helps them squeeze the Brexit Party vote down – something which is particularly important given Nigel Farage’s determination to put up candidates right across the country.Influential Tories are also worried thatthe Lib Dem leader Jo Swinson turns in a barnstorming performance, her party could threaten the Tories in their shire seats.Johnson himself will not do the seven-way debate between the party leaders. The Tories are keen to downplay the importance of this event. I’m told they are considering sending Sajid Javid, Michael Gove, Priti Patel or Rishi Sunak.THE “moratorium” announced on fracking today is a sign of the Tories’ safety-first approach going into this election. They want to close down issues that could cost them seats.One minister defends the decision to abandon the effort to improve the UK’s energy security by saying: “The reality is, it wasn’t happening.”But a bigger factor was their desire not to go into the election with this as a potential vulnerability.I understand that, in stark contrast to , the manesto will be a cautious document designed to prevent handing ammunition to Labour.AT CABINET on Tuesday, Boris Johnson called the Scottish Secretary Alister Jack to speak.An embarrassed Jack explained that he wasn’t actually trying to get in, to which Johnson replied he thought his hand was up.Jack, a multi-millionaire who owns a large farm, then quipped to laughter: “That’s why my farm manager doesn’t let me go to auctions.”THE Tories are planning to accuse Labour of staging a massive raid on the pension pots of million voters.This would hurt the .million who contribute to a private ­pension. Afterwards, one Tory told me Javid’s message was clear: “Labour are coming after your money.”I understand the Tories are also preparing a “tax bombshell” attack on Corbyn.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: greta thunberg leonardo dicaprio friends meeting
story: The movie hunk also revealed he and fellow environmental campaigner Greta, , have “made a commitment to support one another”.The Oscar winning actor – regularly slammed for his use of private jets despite backing environmental causes - said it was an “honour” to speak with the Swedish climate activist.In an Instagram post Leo said he hopes Gretas message is “a wake-up call to world leaders” and told how she makes him “optimistic about what the future holds”.It comes as the schoolgirl launched a bid for help on social media to cross the Atlantic to Spain for the United Nations COP climate conference.The major meeting of world leaders was supposed to be taking place in December in Chile.But protests have been taking place there against the government which has led to serious trouble in the streets.Madrid has now offered to host the summit and it will be considered by the UNs climate body next week.In September DiCaprio came out in support of Greta at a New York conference.And he recently pledged million towards combating the Amazon rain forest fires to protect the lungs of the planet.The Hollywood heavyweight made the announcement through his environmental foundation Earth Alliance.But he is regularly slammed for splurging on private jets and in  emails hacked from film studio Sony showed it was revealed he took six private flights in just six weeks which cost £,.Teenage stigma Greta first hit the headlines in  when she inspired international youth climate strikes and spoke at the Extinction Rebellion protests before she met UK politicians.She shot to fame as the poster-girl for climate change awareness after a picture of her “school strike for climate change” was posted on Facebook by Swedish eco-warrior, Ingmar Rentzhog.Her strike inspired tens of thousands of students from around the world to join her #FridaysforFuture demonstrations - skipping school every Friday to protest climate change.Her work in the UK has included meeting politicians from across the spectrum in Westminster as the Extinction Rebellion protests took place outside.She told them her future and those of other young people had been sold adding: We probably dont even have a future any more.The Swedish teenager grabbed the worlds attention when she staged a School Strike for Climate in front of the Swedish Parliament in August .Greta was driven to take action by a record heatwave in northern Europe and forest fires that ravaged swathes of Swedish land up to the Arctic.The teenager said she is inspired by US civil rights activist Rosa Parks, who refused to give up her seat to a white passenger on a racially segregated bus.I learned she was an introvert, and Im also an introvert, she said.Speaking at the Global Citizen Festival DiCaprio said: Its become clear that our political leaders have failed to live up to promises that we celebrated that day.Our future is being gambled away, and our leaders, those whom we entrust to protect us and set the example, are either failing to stop these dangerous trends or, in some cases, denying the very science of this climate catastrophe.Its not the first time DiCaprio has spoken out against Trump.In  he chastised him for ignoring facts and truths and modern science.A carbon-neutral future is the only way we will inherit a planet capable of sustaining le on Earth as we know it.

title: books for schools launch campaign
story: Some , schools in England, Wales and Northern Ireland will get the chance to get a free pack of books worth more than £. It is simple to get involved. Primary schools can register now at thesun booksforschools until Friday, November . On Saturday, November , we will start printing tokens in the paper for you to collect.Head teacher Frances Ward said: “The Sun’s free books have really caught the children’s imaginations. We can’t wait to start collecting tokens.”To mark the launch, we also speak to top authors, including Michael Morpurgo, about their love for books.  So, what are you waiting for  Join us.. Help your school collect , tokens from The Sun and The Sun on Sunday between Saturday, November , , and Saturday, January , . Once your school has , tokens, they will need tothem by Saturday, February , . Your school will receive the books in March “Stories give us knowledge and understanding. They teach us about our place in the world and we learn what happened in the past and how we can do better in the future. All of those lessons come from books. The gt of reading is the greatest enabling thing we can give a child. So, the fact that the Sun is giving children from all kinds of backgrounds more books is incredible.”The best-selling author, , who has written more than  books, remains one of the hardest-working writers around. He says: “I can’t see a time when I’ll ever stop writing.”Although we have more children’s authors than ever before, Michael says we have a problem. There are thousands of kids who  don’t enjoy reading. The former children’s laureate  says: “It could be for any reason. Perhaps there aren’t enough books at home, or the child hasn’t been read to enough.“Or they don’t have access to a decent library.  Or perhaps the adults in their le don’t have enough enthusiasm for books to make it a priority. Whatever the reason, it’s an issue. It takes one book to change everything. Whether it’s a story by Judith Kerr, David Walliams or one of my books, a child engages in a book they will read another one. But the books have to be there in the first place.Michael’s passion for books is obvious and he believes that, in the digital world, many of us have become lazier when it comes to  teaching children. He says: “Technology is overwhelming everything. It is so much easier to give a child an electronic device. Just by pressing a button, they are entertained without any parental or teaching involvement. But reading is about communicating with other people. And being read to by somebody who cares is so important for children.”The former primary school teacher  from Devon   adds: “Children have the right to have a great school library,   great parents and  great teachers. For a child to get lost in a book they must enjoy it. You will only read stories and poems for pleasureyou’re actually enjoying them. The minute you turn stories into comprehension and tests you wreck the whole thing.”Michael realises that boys in particular can struggle to enjoy reading as they get older, as he also stopped enjoying books as a lad. He says: “As a young boy, I loved Enid Blyton’s stories until I was eight and wanted to turn the page. After that age, there were too many school tests and so much pressure to be able to recite poems word-for-word, it took all of the joy out of stories for me. It wasn’t until I was ten and I read Treasure Island, by Robert Louis Stevenson, that I was hooked again.”In , Michael was awarded a knighthood for services to literature and charity. He remains a passionate ambassador for children’s books and believes that it is through literature that we can talk about sensitive subjects.He says: “The British have always been incredible storytellers and historically we do it very well. If we are to create literary adults who continue to write incredible stories, we need to create literary children. It’s the only way.”IN our tech-heavy world, it has never been more important to remember the huge part books play in a child’s le, says  Dame Jacqueline Wilson. The  Tracy Beaker author, who is backing The Sun’s Books For Schools campaign,  believes we need to  do everything we can to share the love of books.The former children’s laureate, , says: “Campaigns such as this show people care passionately about the importance of books and children reading. Hopefully, it will resonate with  people and act as a ripple-on-a-pond effect. In this day and age, where it is rare for a school to have its own library and librarian, it is  easy to forget about the part the books can play in a child’s le.“Many children grow up in warm, cosy homes and have lots of lovely outings and the latest devices. Although most parents want their child to read well, it seems as though reading together can sometimes be overlooked and not regarded as important. Even at my age, I can’t stop buying books. I’m not sure I’ll  even have enough time to read all of the books I’ve got.”Jacqueline has written an astonishing  novels, including the Tracy Beaker series which was turned into a popular television series for CBBC. She has never been one to shy away from writing about tough subjects such as adoption, orce and mental illness. She says: “I’m very  evangelical about the importance of sharing books with children so that they can learn that stories equal joy from a young age.“If we can encourage that love of books  when young, that will hopefully follow a child for their whole le. The love of stories often  comes after you’ve learnt the mechanics of how to read. That’s when you can become totally absorbed in a story.  Just ten minutes a day of reading a book to a child can make such a huge dference.“Even as a child becomes older, and can read themselves, it’s still great to share books together. I think it’s wonderful when unlikely people such as sportsmen, actresses and musicians talk about how much they love reading and write books. They have a particular power to be able to connect with children who might not relate to nerdy writers like me.“As a child, I adored What Katy Did, and Ballet Shoes by Noel Streatfeild.  I totally immersed myself in that world. I imagined I was going to stage school and my bedroom slippers were ballet shoes.” All I ever wanted to do was write stories and I wrote my first ‘novel’ when I was nine. To this day, books are still my passion.“We talk about the huge benefits for children when reading a story, but it’s such a treat for an adult to read to a child. I know that some parents are shy about reading aloud, but they don’t need to be. Children don’t mindwords are fluffed or mispronounced. Some children  struggle to sit still and listen to a story, which can make it become a chore.“However, parents need to allow the child to do what they need to do in order to be comfortable. They don’t need to sit still, quiet as a mouse, and listen. If they’re happy playing with their Lego or colouring, then let them do that and just read to them. It’s similar to an adult listening to the radio or a podcast. For some children, listening like that is much more enjoyable. Reading for pleasure is truly wonderful, it would be a very sad day indeedwe stopped.”For more information, pick up The Sun.Later this month we’ll start printing tokens in the paper for schools and parents to collect.Once they reach the target, we’ll send out a bumper pack of  Collins Big Cat books, suitable for kids in Reception and Year .Schools can register at thesun booksforschoolsEVERYBODY should have access to books because they help you achieve your dreams, says author Holly Smale. The writer of the hit Geek Girl novel series for teens is backing The Sun’s Books For Schools campaign. Holly, , admits she was obsessed with books from early childhood and where other kids had a favourite teddy, Holly would clutch her copy of Enid Blyton’s The Faraway Tree and take it wherever she went.Holly, from Hertfordshire, says: “Ever since I was a small child I knew I wanted to write stories and I pursued the dream relentlessly. I wouldn’t have achieved my le’s ambitionI wasn’t able to read as often as I wanted to.”As a little girl, Holly was taken to the library with her sister every week. She says: “We didn’t have any money for books and I read so many that my mum couldn’t keep up with me. We went to the library every Saturday and I would take the maximum amount of books, I think it was ten, every single time. My library card felt as though it was a special key which meant I could access anything.“My poor mum would stagger home under the weight of all our books then we’d be back again the following weekend. My little sister was very loyal to one particular book and borrowed Dogger by Shirley Hughes every week. My parents accepted my obsession with reading and the fact I’d hold a book with one hand while eating with the other. By the time I started school I could read and was lucky that there was a whole new selection of books for me. I still use libraries to this day.”School was tricky for Holly. She was badly bullied but was able to channel the experience into Harriet Manners, the heroine of her award-winning young adult novels. She says: “Books have always been there for me through good times and bad times. On a bad day at school, I’d hide in my bedroom and read Anne Of Green Gables. Every book you read becomes a part of you.”There are depressing statistics about the drop in children reading for pleasure, but Holly believes it’s about finding the right story. She says: When I was a girl, Netflix and YouTube didn’t exist. On long, boring days, it was natural to lose yourself in a book, but nowadays youngsters have more choice on how to spend their time.“Sadly, I don’t have time to read ten books a week any more but I usually have two on the go. There are times when I need to turn the telly off or come back earlier from the pub to finish a book. But losing myself in a great story reminds me I’m doing what I love . . . I’ve got the le I wanted as a kid.”IT’S simple to start. All primary schools need to do is visit thesun booksforschools before Friday, November .For more information, pick up The Sun.Later this month we’ll start printing tokens in the paper for schools and parents to collect.Once they reach the target, we’ll send out a bumper pack of  Collins Big Cat books, suitable for kids in Reception and Year .Schools can register at thesun booksforschoolsOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: no deal brexit conservative election manifesto
story: In a step away from his previous “do or die” Brexit pledge Mr Johnson will now focus attention on “getting Brexit done immediately” by pushing his deal through the Commons after the general election in December.The move is thought to try to capture the centre ground and appeal to soft Liberal Democrat voters who have concerns over holding a second EU referendum.In an interview with The Times, Nicky Morgan, the outgoing Culture Secretary, said: “If you vote Conservative at this election, you’re voting to leave with this deal, and no-deal has been effectively been taken off the table.”It is also thought the party’s manesto, expected to be published in a fortnight, will also commit to tax cuts and breaks.These include:On the issue of whether income tax is too high, she said: “A Conservative government will always be a tax-cutting government.“We have raised the personal tax free allowance to let people keep much more of their own hard-earned cash. title: general election voting twice register bournemouth university student
story: ‘Lucy’, , is said to be studying at Bournemouth University and her Twitter message has exposed the weaknesses of the country’s electoral system.The student vote could become a key factor in the outcome of December’s general election with any potential infringements on the regulations possibly impacting on the final result.According to The Daily Mail, her Twitter message said: “I have just re-registered for both my hometown AND UNI address… in under  seconds! If you live at a second address… ADD it to the register and you can vote TWICE. Register twice. Be brave.”‘Lucy’, who was given an alias, registered to vote both at her university address and her parents’ home in a suburb of Birmingham – which she is entitled to do under the law.However the controversy arises not with her registering twice but with her encouragement of voting twice, which would be an illegal act.Under electoral rules you can only cast one vote in just one constituency, breaking that rule could see you face a £, fine.When contacted by the Mail, Lucy’s father, , took a dim view of his daughter’s actions.He said: “Oh, interesting, she shouldn’t be doing that. I’ll be having a word with her to tell her to do something about this. I definitely don’t condone this at all. I’ll be on the phone to her very shortly.”In the previous general election in  Jeremy Corbyn-backing students in places such as Canterbury and Lincoln were blamed for causing political upsets where Conservative victories had been predicted.In Canterbury, which had been a solid Tory seat for decades, Labour took the seat after it saw its share of the vote nearly double to  per cent.In Lincoln, which has a student population of around ,, saw Labour’s share of the vote rise by . per cent.In two electoral wards, where most of the students in Lincoln live, the turnout for polling was said to have jumped by  per cent or more.At the time the University of Lincoln authorities told the former Tory MP Karl McCartney, that it would be normal for only - per cent of students registered to vote at one hall of residence, The Junxion, to turn up to do so, because many would have already left the city for the summer break.But  per cent of registered students from the hall of residence voted, with none of their votes cast by proxy or by post.Mr McCartney, who is hoping to regain his seat at the Tory candidate, told the Mail he suspected he lost his seat due to plans orchestrated by the Labour group Momentum.Following the  he claims to have discovered two students from The Junxion pictured together in Greece on social media on the election day, although both were listed in polling records to have voted in person in Lincoln.Mr McCartney said: ‘I am not saying these two students were at fault.“But were their polling cards pinched from the hall of residence after they left to go abroad  Did the stealing of polling cards of absent students happen multiple times at The Junxion “Did student activists find the polling cards lying around and go to vote, pretending to be someone  ”Mr McCartney also claimed five Lincoln constituents were prevented from voting saying that when they got to their polling station at around mid-morning, someone had already used their name and address to vote.He said: “I am told that the five had all been visited on their doorsteps by Momentum’s Labour canvassers in the previous few days.“The constituents had told the Labour activists that they were not going to vote, or did not normally vote, but later changed their minds.”Mr McCartney said he had reported his concerns to the Electoral Commission but no action was ever taken.“His claims smack of someone grasping for excuses for their failure.Momentum members put in hard, honest work to secure a Labour MP in Lincoln and we deny any allegations of wrongdoing.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. The appeal seeks a special commemoration of serving personnel and former personnel who “lost their lives in defence of the nation as surely as those who died on the battlefield.” It is backed by three ex-Services chiefs and former England football captain Terry Butcher, whose soldier son Christopher died following a struggle with PTSD. The campaign is calling for the names of all those who took their own lives to be added to the Armed Forces memorial at the National Arboretum in Staffordshire. Around  serving and former personnnel have committed suicide since the beginning of . At least  troops have died this year, a  per cent rise on this stage of .    Former Ipswich and Rangers star Terry, now , said his son and hundreds of others like him were also victims of war. Christopher, a Royal Artillery captain, had been haunted by nightmares and flashbacks about Afghanistan. The -year-old had been diagnosed with severe PTSD and medically discharged from the Army. Dad Terry said: “Those soldiers’ names should be on the wall as they were also victims of war along with those already engraved. “Their deaths were a direct result of the conflict and the total lack of medical help and assistance afterwards.” The campaign is led by Jo Jukes, whose Iraq War veteran husband Dave killed himself last year after suffering from PTSD for more than a decade.  Jo, , a Birmingham mum of two, said: “We need a memorial to show that veterans who took their own lives after being diagnosed with service-attributable mental health conditions died because they served their country. “They may not have died on the battlefield but the mental wounds they received in fighting for this country in Iraq, Afghanistan, the Balkans and Northern Ireland are just as real.” The plea is also supported by General the Lord Dannatt and General Sir Mike Jackson, both former heads of the Army, and ex-Navy chief Lord West of Spithead.  Lord Dannatt said: “It’s a very sad reality that those who have taken their own lives as a result of losing their personal battles with PTSD, are as much the fatalities of war as those who have lost their lives in combat.” General Jackson said: “I whole-heartedly support the proposal for a suitable memorial.” Lord West added: “It is appropriate that their sacrice is commemorated and I can think of no better place than the National Arboretum.”

story: NewsCon artists use Ed Sheeran and Harry Potter in fake university swindleThe singer and boy wizard were highlighted in publicity for the bogus College of Suffolk, as Ed lives in the county and Harry was born thereShareCommentsByLorraine King:,  NOV NewsEd Sheeran and Harry Potter were highlighted in publicity for the bogus College of Suffolk"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailEd Sheeran and Harry Potter have been used to try to con would-be students out of thousands of pounds in a fake university scam. The singer and boy wizard were highlighted in publicity for the bogus College of Suffolk, as Ed lives in the county and Harry was born there. Trading standards chiefs have now shut a website promoting the “college” which used a photo of the real University of Suffolk, based in Ipswich. The fake college offered degree courses in acting, musical theatre, dance and performance art, with fees from £, to £, a year.  Trading standards believe the scam was aimed at overseas students looking to obtain a British degree. Investigators say it is not known whether anyone was conned by the website. But Suffolk Trading Standards’ spokeswoman Sasha Watson said: “The courses would have been a real draw to someone who wanted to get into these industries.” The website, which went live in April, said it was “shaping an amazing future for  students”. It largely tried to entice them by emphasising Suffolk’s links with Ed and Harry.    Ed, , was raised in Framlingham and still lives nearby, while all Harry Potter fans know he was born in Lavenham village. Also, a th century house there featured in the film Harry Potter and The Deathly Hallows Part One.   The website said that apart from Ed, other famous faces to see around the county include chef Delia Smith, actor Ralph Fiennes and novelist Anthony Horowitz. “Look out for them when you’re out and about – you could have quite a collection of autographs,” it said.  It claimed that the college was founded in  and had a section written by its“President”, calling himself Dr Stephen Spinks.

title: family six living daily nightmare
story: NewsFamily of six living daily nightmare stuck in one filthy room in shared houseCraig Simmonds and Roxanne Stamford have been forced to move their family around caravans, hotels and temporary accommodation after falling into the gaps with local authoritiesShareCommentsByTristan Cork:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsThe family say they are living a daily nightmare"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA family of six say they are aposliving a daily nightmareapos, forced to stay in one filthy room of a shared house. Craig Simmonds and Roxanne Stamford, who have one disabled child and a young baby, are bringing up their family in the tiny room - which had blood stains on the bedding and mice droppings on the carpet. The couple told to Bristol Live they had to threaten Bristol City Council with an emergency court injunction just to get a room for the night. The family said they have fallen into the gaps, with two local authorities - Bristol and Cornwall Council - both attempting to deny they are responsible for housing them. Over the last few months, they say they have been moved around constantly, from a caravan in Cornwall to hotels and temporary accommodation until they ended up in a House of Multiple Occupancy in Southville, Bristol. Craig and Roxanne arrived at the room in Southville in the middle of October, after four days in an emergency tourist holiday let AirBnB in the city centre. They found the accommodation had a double bed and a bunk bed.The bedding was blood-stained, the room and the tiny en-suite shower-room was filthy, with mouse droppings evident and a dirty carpet, toilet and cooking area. The next day, after sending images of the state of the place to Bristol City Council, an emergency ‘deep clean’ was arranged.    And there, the family of six have remained, waiting in limbo while two local authorities  miles apart argue the other is responsible for housing them. The couple’s ordeal began last year when Roxanne suffered from serious post-natal depression and other mental health issues following the birth of her youngest child, Aimee. Roxanne and Craig lived in Cornwall, where Craig worked long hours as a chef.Roxanne’s illness meant he kept having to take time off work to care for her and his children, and so he lost his job, and the couple fell into rent arrears on their council house in Camborne. They were eventually evicted by Cornwall Council on May  this year, and have not had a permanent home since. Craig is born and bred in Bristol.When he was nine, escaping an abusive relationship, his mum moved the family to Cornwall, where he then lived. He grew up, met Roxanne, started a family and his mum Lou was a huge help as the couple - at that point - had three children, Catelynn, Freddie and Harry. Freddie, particularly, needed more help - he has a range of special needs, including cerebral palsy, and has to have his legs rubbed vigorously after any exercise. But three years ago, Lou ‘retired’ back to her native South Bristol, moving into an over-s flat in Stockwood, and when Aimee arrived last year, Craig and Roxanne struggled on their own. So when they were evicted by Cornwall Council on May , the couple didn’t know where  to go, but to put all their belongings into a family member’s car, and drive up the M to Bristol. “I didn’t want the kids to see the bailfs actually come and chuck us out, I couldn’t bear that to happen,” said Roxanne, who is pregnant. “So I left the keys with a neighbour and we left the day before, on April , before the bailfs came.” They squeezed in to Lou’s flat for a couple of nights, and presented themselves at  Temple Street, Bristol City Council’s housing department headquarters.   The couple were put into a three-bed house, albeit temporarily, in Bedminster.The three older children were enrolled into their local primary school and as a skilled chef, Craig got a job quickly at a local pub. “Everything was sorted, or seemed to be,” said Craig. “The school was amazing, the kids settled in really well, they loved going to school, and I got a job. The house was nice, and I thought we would be ok.” But behind the scenes, it appears a conflict was brewing between Bristol City Council and Cornwall Council. As the family went through the process of applying for more permanent housing, they were told there was a problem. Craig’s ‘local links’ didn’t meet the criteria. He hadn’t been an adult in Bristol. He and his family hadn’t lived in Bristol for more than six months.  His family link to his mum didn’t count either - any family member has to have lived in Bristol for five years for that to count, and Lou only moved back to the city three years ago. Bristol is a city still in the grips of a housing crisis, despite new homes being built in their hundreds.There are , people on the housing waiting list, and  families in temporary accommodation. As the summer began, the family were told they would have to go back to Cornwall, and present themselves as homeless there, not in Bristol. It was Harry’s sixth birthday, the day the children were taken out of Parson Street School and driven back down the M to be put into a single room in a shared house in Newquay. “It was awful. At am there were people drunk or on drugs, banging on the door, shouting they were going to kill us. The children were terried,” said Craig.    Cornwall Council kept moving them around places like that, including for a spell, into a caravan.By mid-August, the new school year was looming and Roxanne was desperate to provide some stability for her children. “Trying to get the kids into school was an absolute nightmare. Cornwall Council told us they would have to go to school, but allocated the three of them three dferent schools, which was just impossible,” said Craig. Then, Craig said Cornwall Council told them their efforts to find them a home had failed, and hit them with another bombshell. “They told us we had made ourselves intentionally homeless, because we left the day before the bailfs came,” Roxanne said, as she fought back the tears. “They told us that there was nothing more they could do, and we would have to find our own privately rented accommodation, and pay for it with our housing benefit. “I spent weeks searching for somewhere to live. It was impossible. We didn’t have a guarantor.There is absolutely nowhere in Cornwall that will take a family of six on benefits in private rented accommodation,” she said.    The day came - October  - when Cornwall Council’s temporary accommodation ended, and the family were out on the streets again.For the second time, they made the trip back up the M.On Monday, October , they presented themselves again at  Temple Street, and were told that,  Bristol City Council had no duty to house them, they were Cornwall’s problem. In desperation the kids about to leave school and with nowhere to stay that night, they went to the offices of homeless charity Shelter. Shocked officials there immediately summoned their legal department, and a stf request threatening an emergency court appeal meant that Bristol City Council’s housing staff accepted that they could not, after all, leave a family of six, with four children under the age of eight, including a baby, on the streets. A housing officer used a corporate credit card to book an AirBnB.    They were told they would be staying three nights, and again on Thursday morning, were waiting at the council offices to be told where to go next. Finding them a place to live appears to have been handed over to Connolly  Callaghan, which runs a huge number of temporary accommodation units in Bristol. CC initially told them to go to a two-bed flat in Fishponds, but then told them it was flooded. After telling CC that their children’s school was in Bedminster, they were sent to a room in an HMO in Southville. “We arrived and the front door was open, the door to the room was open and we were told this was it,” said Roxanne. “There was blood stains on the bed. The kids walked in and sat down on the floor and I looked at the floor and it was filthy,” she added. “The state of the little bathroom was worse - one of my kids looked at it and refused to go in it - we go to Asda when he needs the loo.” The family have applied to be accepted onto the waiting list in Bristol.

story: NewsHorried campers saw woman trying to escape caravan before fatal clf plungeMum-of-three Elvira Ferraii died when her caravan was blown off a clf at Eco Beach Camping and Caravanning Park in Connemara, County GalwayShareCommentsByJohn FallonMilo Boyd:,  NOV NewsThe Swiss nurse tried but failed to get out of the falling caravan "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCampers looked on in horror as a nurse franticly tried to escape a caravan before it plunged off clfs onto a rocky beach below. Mum-of-three Elvira Ferraii was staying at a remote beauty spot in County Galway when the violent Storm Ali battered Ireland and the UK with mph winds and heavy rain in September .Following a ferociously stormy night fellow camper Sally Forth got out of her tent at around .am on September  to spot Ms Ferrariaposs caravan sliding towards a clf edge, The Irish Mirror reported .She could see the Swiss woman desperately trying to get out of the mobile home through the open door before it disappeared over the clf edge.  Caleb-Amie Soltendieck, from Quebec in Canada, raced down to the beach after watching the vehicle fall  feet. He found the caravan partly submerged in water on top of Ms Ferrari’s body, which he managed to pull clear from the wreckage. Despite his attempts to resuscitate her it was immediately clear to Mr Soltendieck that she was dead, an inquest in Galway heard. Garda Shane Nally said the caravan was searched to checkanyone  was in it and that the body of Ms Ferrari was taken to University Hospital Galway for a post mortem. Her belongings, including a bicycle helmet, were scattered on the beach in the aftermath of the tragedy.    Although strong winds were predicted that day, the sheer strength of Storm Ali had taken those at the Eco Beach Camping and Caravanning Park in Connemara by surprise. The siteaposs owners Kris and Tatjama Acton had offered Ms Ferrari use of a mobile home in a more sheltered location night before the storm, which she had turned down.Coast Guard officer Michael Murray, who lives close to the camp site, said weather forecasters had underestimated the strength of the storm.He said: “The forecast was well off. It was near hurricane force, a severe storm.” Mr Murray added that he had to move his Toyota Landcruiser jeep, which he had parked close to where the caravan had been positioned, because it was being moved by the wind. Coroner Dr Ciaran MacLoughlin said the death was a tragic accident.    “There is no way this could have been foreseen, a storm of that nature is most unusual at that time of year, he told the court. The coroner said the wind swept the caravan away as Ms Ferrari tried to get out and that it came down on top of her on the beach, causing fatal injuries. Pathologist Dr Ramada Shatwan said that the cause of death was a severe traumatic head injury which led to a fractured skull and crushed brain tissue. He said there were no other fractured bones and that all organs were normal. Ms Ferrari lived in Steinmaur, a municipality north of Zurich, where she studied Alzheimeraposs disease.

Back in  Annie Leibovitz was asked to take four official photos of the Monarch to celebrate the Queenaposs visit to the US. However confusion around the logistics meant it was reported that the Queen aposstormed outapos after clips from the shoot featured in the trailer for a BBC documentary. It later became known as Queengate and the BBC ended up apologising. However, the bad publicity around the shoot stayed with the Monarch and years later she decided she wanted to do something to fix things with Annie. Nine years after the photoshoot, the Queen sat down with her dressmaker and close friend Angela Kelly to discuss how they could make things right.    Writing in her new book The Other Side of the Coin, Angela explains what actually happened. She claims that the Queen was due to just meet Annie and her daughter, but when she arrived there were more than  people in the room. She simply didnapost have time to speak to them all, so left to go to the photo shoot as had always been the plan.    Angela writes: One of the good things about working in the same job for such a long time is that it allows you to put things right that havenapost quite gone as planned in the past. I have always felt so bad for Annie about how this was late reported, as she really didnapost deserve to be misrepresented in this way. So Angela suggested that the Queen ask Annie to take the official photos for her th birthday - and the Monarch loved the idea. The Queen was more than happy and in full agreement that it would be the right thing to do to make amends for the earlier misunderstanding, and she said yes. After they had discussed what they wanted from the official photos, Angela travelled to New York to personally ask Annieshe would take the pictures. When I told her that the Queen had asked for her toto photograph her on or close to her ninetieth birthday, Annie was thrilled and humbled to receive such an honour. Annie and her team flew to the UK over the Easter weekend to take the photos while the Royal Family were all together for the holiday. They took four photos which were shared around the world to mark the landmark birthday - with one of her with her great-grandchildren, including Prince George and Princess Charlotte, getting all of the attention.    There was also a photo of the Queen with her daughter Princess Anne, one of her with Prince Philip and another of her dressed down outside with her beloved corgis. Angela writes: The great-grandchildren were all so well behaved, and I think even they were excited about having a group photograph taken with the Queen. But th real stars of the show that day were the corgis. They knew how to work the camera, looking straight at Annie while she was taking the photos. The Queen was delighted with the pictures, which were very special family photos to be shared with the public.    Speaking about the incident back in , Annie said: The morning of the shoot the Queen came walking down the hall very purposely. But they had been following her around for months. There microphone picked up her saying: aposIaposve had enough of dressing like this thank you very muchapos, as she marched down the hall.    It appeared the Queen was stomping out of the photo session, rather than going into it, the photographer added. Leibovitz said the Queen was  minutes late as she had to get into the complicated ceremonial outfit for the pictures. Once the Queen was in position Leibovitz asked to take off her crown. She said: I asked hershe would remove the tiara, I said it looked a little dressy.

Nicola Ward says she would catastrophise about ious situations that could happen to her while she was in her car.  The -year-old said she would feel like Iaposm in turmoil when in the car and that driving would leave her feeling absolutely exhausted.  The small business owner from Reading noticed her driving anxiety started when she moved out of London and away from city le to the suburbs, to start a family. She drives on a daily basis but since the birth of her daughter, Sydney, her anxiety in the car has signicantly increased and says sheaposs always ‘on high alert’ whilst driving. Nicola admits she does not trust other motorists to follow the highway code and panics when she gets stuck in traffic.  She told Mirror: I need my car on a daily basis to get to work and for childcare so itaposs not something I can stop doing. I always feel most vulnerable when my baby is in the car. Things got worse after I had a collision in Spring  when someone drove into me. After that I was extremely jumpy in the car. I started noticing and envisioning things happening and I would catastrophise situations. I would look in my rear view mirror and was certain that someone would drive into the back of me.   Iaposd have extreme thoughts like I would be driving under a bridge and I would be terried it would collapse. If I was stuck in traffic I would be extremely worried that Iaposd never get out of the jam and would plan my escape route. I was feeling constantly on edge while driving. I was unsettled and could never relax. I just wanted to get to where I was going.    Nicola shared her experience as it was revealed nearly a third of UK drivers have suffered a near miss on the roads due to feelings of anxiety, according to new research commissioned by ST CENTRAL Insurance and leading mental health charity, SANE. The research forms part of a new joint campaign launched earlier this month dedicated to raising awareness of anxiety and the threat it presents on our roads. SANE has also developed a suite of practical advice to address this problem, by helping motorists tackle feelings of anxiety. To help address this issue and improve driver safety, ST CENTRAL has partnered with SANE to provide advice for how drivers might tackle feelings of anxiousness both before and during driving: .     Before the journey ask yourself: are you safe to drive  Consider whether it’s worth taking the journey at all. If you must travel, could you take public transport instead, or call a taxi  .     Pull over and stop at the earliest and safest opportunity. If you begin to feel anxious while driving, breathing exercises and meditation techniques can help ease the feelings of anxiety once safely stopped. .     Be mindful of noise. Don’t be afraid to ask passengers to keep the noise down. If you listen to music, consider opting for songs with a lower tempo, or music you find calming. .     Think about your environment. Keeping the car clean and tidy could help create a calm atmosphere. You could consider putting lavender, which can be soothing, in their car to create a relaxed atmosphere. .     If you’re a passenger, and you feel unsafe due to a driver that appears to be feeling anxious, consider gently suggesting stopping for a toilet break or for a soft drink.
